natural problem:

natural solution: Let the roots of $(x - \sqrt[3]{13})(x - \sqrt[3]{53})(x - \sqrt[3]{103}) = 0$ be $\alpha,$ $\beta,$ and $\gamma.$  Then by Vieta's formulas, \begin{align} r + s + t &= \alpha + \beta + \gamma, \\ rs + rt + st &= \alpha \beta + \alpha \gamma + \beta \gamma, \\

rst &= \alpha \beta \gamma + \frac{1}{3}. \end{align}We have the factorization \[r^3 + s^3 + t^3 - 3rst = (r + s + t)((r + s + t)^2 - 3(rs + rt + st)).\]Thus, from the equations above, \[r^3 + s^3 + t^3 - 3rst = \alpha^3 + \beta^3 + \gamma^3 - 3 \alpha \beta \gamma.\]Hence, \begin{align}

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes r s t :: real
assumes h0 : "(r - 13 powr (1/3)) * (s - 53 powr (1/3)) * (t - 103 powr (1/3)) = 1 / 3"
and h1 : "r \<noteq> s"
and h2 : "r \<noteq> t"
and h3 : "s \<noteq> t"
shows  "r powr 3 + s powr 3 + t powr 3 = 170"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The equation
\[(x - \sqrt[3]{13})(x - \sqrt[3]{53})(x - \sqrt[3]{103}) = \frac{1}{3}\]has three distinct solutions $r,$ $s,$ and $t.$  Calculate the value of $r^3 + s^3 + t^3.$ The final Answer is 170
 ### Proof
 Let the roots of $(x - \sqrt[3]{13})(x - \sqrt[3]{53})(x - \sqrt[3]{103}) = 0$ be $\alpha,$ $\beta,$ and $\gamma.$  Then by Vieta's formulas, \begin{align} r + s + t &= \alpha + \beta + \gamma, \\ rs + rt + st &= \alpha \beta + \alpha \gamma + \beta \gamma, \\
 rst &= \alpha \beta \gamma + \frac{1}{3}. \end{align}We have the factorization \[r^3 + s^3 + t^3 - 3rst = (r + s + t)((r + s + t)^2 - 3(rs + rt + st)).\]Thus, from the equations above, \[r^3 + s^3 + t^3 - 3rst = \alpha^3 + \beta^3 + \gamma^3 - 3 \alpha \beta \gamma.\]Hence, \begin{align}
 r^3 + s^3 + t^3 &= \alpha^3 + \beta^3 + \gamma^3 + 3(rst - \alpha \beta \gamma) \\ &= 13 + 53 + 103 + 1 \\ &= \boxed{170}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes r s t :: real
assumes h0 : "(r - 13 powr (1/3)) * (s - 53 powr (1/3)) * (t - 103 powr (1/3)) = 1 / 3"
and h1 : "r \<noteq> s"
and h2 : "r \<noteq> t"
and h3 : "s \<noteq> t"
shows  "r powr 3 + s powr 3 + t powr 3 = 170"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find three distinct real numbers $r$, $s$, and $t$ such that $(r - \sqrt[3]{13})(s - \sqrt[3]{53})(t - \sqrt[3]{103}) = \frac{1}{3}$, and $r^3 + s^3 + t^3 = 170$.

 Let the roots of $(x - \sqrt[3]{13})(x - \sqrt[3]{53})(x - \sqrt[3]{103}) = 0$ be $\alpha,$ $\beta,$ and $\gamma.$  Then by Vieta's formulas, \begin{align} r + s + t &= \alpha + \beta + \gamma, \\ rs + rt + st &= \alpha \beta + \alpha \gamma + \beta \gamma, \\

 r^3 + s^3 + t^3 &= \alpha^3 + \beta^3 + \gamma^3 + 3(rst - \alpha \beta \gamma) \\ &= 13 + 53 + 103 + 1 \\ &= \boxed{170}. \end{align}
 *)

shows  "r powr 3 + s powr 3 + t powr 3 = 170"

(* ### Problem

 *)

fixes r s t x :: real

and h1 : "r \<noteq> s \<and> r \<noteq> t \<and> s \<noteq> t"
and h2 : "r = root 3 13"
and h3 : "s = root 3 53"
and h4 : "t = root 3 103"
shows  "r^3 + s^3 + t^3 = 170"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
